text: [Music]
the Ganges flows 2,500 kilometers from
the Himalayas across northern India and
into Bangladesh it rides water and
livelihoods for millions and his sacred
to Hindus but every day around 3 billion
litres of sewage flows into it
that's over a thousand Olympic swimming
pools worth waste and only around half
of it has been through a water treatment
facility Indian Prime Minister Modi
promised to clean it up when he was
elected in 2015 he committed 3 billion
u.s. dollars for a five-year project to
clean the Ganges by 2020 so how
successful has he been cleaning the
river is a monumental task hundreds of
cities sit on its banks industrial waste
household pollution water extraction
farming damming and the cremation of
human remains have all affected the
river there has been a cleanup of
sunbathing areas and a clamp down on the
dumping of toxic waste however recent
parliamentary questioning revealed that
since the beginning of the 2014-15
financial year till November 2018 only
around 720 million u.s. dollars has been
spent and only 63 out of 236 cleaner
projects have been completed a big issue
is that currently working water
treatment facilities can't keep up with
the increase in sewage a 2018 draft
report by India's central Pollution
Control Board suggests that only 4 out
of 41 locations in the river tested as
clean or almost clean so the promise to
clean up the Ganges seems to have fallen
short of the promises made so will it
ever be clean interestingly Germany is
helping finance the upgrade in sewage
treatment facilities on the ganges and
one of their diplomats told the Indian
authorities that it took local River
municipalities 30 years and around 45
billion euros to clean up the River
Rhine but the Ganges is twice as long as
the Rhine
you
